channel.title: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card
channel.description: http://www.killernic.com/ads/lags-worst-enemy/Google/features.html does anyone have it and what to share comments on the product I am interested.

item.title: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

To me that implies that they just have custom rules shipped with it by default, but you could be right. I didn’t see that

If you are right, then thats pretty despicable.

EDIT: I’ve emailed them to find out which it is, under the guise of an interested customer

Read full topic
item.source: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card

item.title: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman:

Iptables is an application licensed under the gpl which helps you manipulate the routing stack (and other things) in the Linux kernel. By “stock iptables” I meant that they don’t need to modify the app at all, they just distribute it along with their “firmware”.

You would be right if it was stock iptables, however:

[quote=“http://www.killernic.com/ads/lags-worst-enemy/Google/features.html”]Hardware Firewall
Stops intruders with no impact on your game performance, based on a custom Linux iptables firewall implementation.[/quote]

The said it was ‘based on a custom linux iptables firewall implementation’, which seems to imply that they modified it, and therefore have to distribute the source, right?

Read full topic
item.source: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card

item.title: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

The Foundations of the GPL

Nobody should be restricted by the software they use. There are four freedoms that every user should have:

* the freedom to use the software for any purpose,</blockquote>

They only use the software, and as long as they don’t modify it there is no use of distributing the source as it’s already available.

Read full topic
item.source: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card

item.title: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Iptables is an application licensed under the gpl which helps you manipulate the routing stack (and other things) in the Linux kernel. By “stock iptables” I meant that they don’t need to modify the app at all, they just distribute it along with their “firmware”.

An analogy: selling a computer with Ubuntu preinstalled does not violate the gpl.

Read full topic
item.source: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card

item.title: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

I don’t know what ‘stock iptables’ are, but if they are some sort of output of a program Mopman is right.

Read full topic
item.source: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card

item.title: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

If your firmware was a derivative of iptables, sure. But the chances are, since theres a processor on there, its a linux kernel with some mini subset of tools (Busybox possibly, like most @home routers), running iptables + whatever custom software they need to do what they’re doing. All you are doing there is distributing stock iptables, which dosen’t contravene the GPL at all as far as I can see (anyone feel free to point out the mistake, I’m only right most of the time :D)

Read full topic
item.source: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card

item.title: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card
item.dc:creator: @ThatOneServer Mike_
item.description:
@ThatOneServer wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:15, topic:241229”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=317552.msg2543143#msg2543143 date=1227119990]

I don’t want the network card to bypass my network stack because I already have performance enhancing tweaks on my network stack.

It says they use linux iptables based technology, does that mean that their firmware is open source? It better be or I smell a lawsuit coming on…

Erm, why?

You don’t have to open source your firmware if you create an embedded device that happens to run GNU/Linux. That’s like saying if you buy Dell PC that comes with Linux installed, their BIOS firmware and any other apps they happen to distribute with it have to be Open Sourced.
[/quote]

Part of it has to be open-sourced at least.[/quote]
doesn’t gpl say that if you anything that is gpl your project must be open sauce?

Read full topic
item.source: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card

item.title: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card
item.dc:creator: @k00dr k00dr
item.description:
@k00dr wrote:

[quote=“runescape3dude, post:22, topic:241229”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=317552.msg2553014#msg2553014 date=1227731557]

I don’t want the network card to bypass my network stack because I already have performance enhancing tweaks on my network stack.

It says they use linux iptables based technology, does that mean that their firmware is open source? It better be or I smell a lawsuit coming on…

Erm, why?

You don’t have to open source your firmware if you create an embedded device that happens to run GNU/Linux. That’s like saying if you buy Dell PC that comes with Linux installed, their BIOS firmware and any other apps they happen to distribute with it have to be Open Sourced.

Part of it has to be open-sourced at least.

No, no it dosen’t.

You people should really read the GPL
[/quote]
Isn’t that like 300 pages or something?[/quote]

99999999999999 pages:

http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-3.0-standalone.html

Read full topic

I don’t want the network card to bypass my network stack because I already have performance enhancing tweaks on my network stack.

It says they use linux iptables based technology, does that mean that their firmware is open source? It better be or I smell a lawsuit coming on…

Erm, why?

You don’t have to open source your firmware if you create an embedded device that happens to run GNU/Linux. That’s like saying if you buy Dell PC that comes with Linux installed, their BIOS firmware and any other apps they happen to distribute with it have to be Open Sourced.

Part of it has to be open-sourced at least.

Isn’t that like 300 pages or something?

item.title: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Miss Silabsoft:

http://www.killernic.com/ads/lags-worst-enemy/Google/features.html does anyone have it and what to share comments on the product I am interested.

I have one, its works alright, I mainly use it to show off to my friends for the looks of it. When im not I just use my 10/100/1000 on my mobo.

Well, let me take back what I said, I use it for when im playing an FPS game, but for something like runescape and browsing the internet you see no difference. For me in FPS games it helps out alot.

Read what this guy wrote on newegg for the 209 one.

Dannukesem on 12/19/2007

Read full topic

item.title: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:15, topic:241229”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=317552.msg2543143#msg2543143 date=1227119990]

I don’t want the network card to bypass my network stack because I already have performance enhancing tweaks on my network stack.

It says they use linux iptables based technology, does that mean that their firmware is open source? It better be or I smell a lawsuit coming on…

Erm, why?

You don’t have to open source your firmware if you create an embedded device that happens to run GNU/Linux. That’s like saying if you buy Dell PC that comes with Linux installed, their BIOS firmware and any other apps they happen to distribute with it have to be Open Sourced.
[/quote]

Part of it has to be open-sourced at least.[/quote]

No, no it dosen’t.

You people should really read the GPL

item.title: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:17, topic:241229”][quote author=rulereric link=topic=317552.msg2550191#msg2550191 date=1227472088]
You have a internet pipe and its limited in size. You have packets from many things like your uploading movies and playing cs. What a product like this may allow you is to put packets from cs always at the top of the queue. Of course can be done with best performance at the hardware level right before the packet hits the wire.[/quote]

QoS? I have that on my router. (dd-wrt is awesome)[/quote]
any linksys router you can install ddwrt on should already have qos…

Read full topic

What a product like this may allow you is to put packets from cs always at the top of the queue. Of course can be done with best performance at the hardware level right before the packet hits the wire.[/quote]cus we all know how much 0.0000000000001s means in cs

item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:13, topic:241229”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=317552.msg2519361#msg2519361 date=1225809125]
I don’t want the network card to bypass my network stack because I already have performance enhancing tweaks on my network stack.

It says they use linux iptables based technology, does that mean that their firmware is open source? It better be or I smell a lawsuit coming on…
[/quote]

Erm, why?

You don’t have to open source your firmware if you create an embedded device that happens to run GNU/Linux. That’s like saying if you buy Dell PC that comes with Linux installed, their BIOS firmware and any other apps they happen to distribute with it have to be Open Sourced.[/quote]

Part of it has to be open-sourced at least.

item.title: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:13, topic:241229”]Erm, why?

You don’t have to open source your firmware if you create an embedded device that happens to run GNU/Linux. That’s like saying if you buy Dell PC that comes with Linux installed, their BIOS firmware and any other apps they happen to distribute with it have to be Open Sourced.[/quote]
I think he means the firmware they wrote for it uses iptables, and iptables in GPL software, so they would have to open source the firmware because it uses iptables.

Also, don’t buy this!

Read full topic
item.source: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card

item.title: Anyone have a Killer NIC gaming Network card
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:3, topic:241229”]I don’t want the network card to bypass my network stack because I already have performance enhancing tweaks on my network stack.

It says they use linux iptables based technology, does that mean that their firmware is open source? It better be or I smell a lawsuit coming on…[/quote]

Erm, why?

You don’t have to open source your firmware if you create an embedded device that happens to run GNU/Linux. That’s like saying if you buy Dell PC that comes with Linux installed, their BIOS firmware and any other apps they happen to distribute with it have to be Open Sourced.

Read full topic
